instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1370: What is A1370? A1370 is a model number for a 11 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2010, Mid 2011 with EMC 2393, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2796, 820-3024..
definitions.820-2855: What is 820-2855? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG? PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG Is a single phase of CPU VCORE for the graphics processor integrated into the CPU before it is combined into one PPVCORE_S0_AXG rail.
definitions.820-3024: What is 820-3024? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-2796: What is 820-2796? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.CPUIMVP_PGOOD: What is CPUIMVP_PGOOD? CPUIMVP_PGOOD is a signal from the CPU VCORE buck converter IC that indicates CPU power is good which is necessary to create PM_S0_PGOOD..
definitions.820-3023: What is 820-3023? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.message:
Hi,
I've tried to figure out the exact model of the board, but I can't find it engraved on the board anywhere.
The only number that I saw was this one on the img, glued on that component, and because i found a boardview with that exact number, I assumed that it was the board number. Isen't it?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1370</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2855</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A CLEAN ME
threads.message: That's the lid sensor board number.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1370</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2855</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A CLEAN ME
threads.message:
Hi,
I can't figure out what is the board number. I can't see it anywhere.
However, I'm not sure that the problem is the BIOS.

This mac has green light, fan spin, all the voltages are present, but i get no image (internal nor external), and i don't have USB activity.

The CPU gets hot, and i get all voltages, besides:

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG</SIGNAL> = 0V

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1370</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2855</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A CLEAN ME
threads.message:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://logi.wiki/index.php/Board_Number_by_A_Number#<SIGNAL>A1370_MACBOOK_AIR_11</SIGNAL>.<SIGNAL>22_MAGSAFE_1</SIGNAL>[/URL]
[QUOTE]
[SIZE=5][B]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1370</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Air 11" MagSafe 1[/B][/SIZE]

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2796</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2010 MacBook Air 11"
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2011 MacBook Air 11"[/QUOTE]

[ATTACH type="full"]60001[/ATTACH]

It was hiden...
It is <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1370</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2855</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A CLEAN ME
threads.message:
Do you get voltage at L7510?
Check <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_PGOOD</SIGNAL> too.

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, all present?

Hi,
Yes, i have voltages on  L7510:
1=1V
2= 1.1V

<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_PGOOD</SIGNAL>  = 3.3V

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> =3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> =3.4V
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> =3.3V
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> =3.3V

threads.message:
I've tried the K78 no test.bin, but the result is the same.

With the other one (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>), the behavier change. It seams that it tries to boot, the fan spin for 1-2 seconds, and then stops, and keeps like that forever (looping spin and stop), and goes from 200 mA to 30 mA on bench PSU.

threads.message:

This BIOS seams to be the correct one (the mac powered on, and rebooted after a while, and stayed powered on normaly after that reboot). 
However, i still don't have any image, internal or external, and no aparent USB activity.
On bench PSU it reaches around 700mA, and stays on (fan spin).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1370</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2855</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A CLEAN ME
threads.message: Do you get voltage on both L7510/50?

threads.message: On L7510 I get 1.1V. On L7550 I get near 0V (0.0010V)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1370</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2855</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A CLEAN ME
threads.message:
Some old boards get AXG voltage directly when boot.
I'm not sure in this case, compare with good board.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1370</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2855</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A CLEAN ME
threads.message: I don't have any other board like this one. Is there any other way to be sute? Can I measure something else?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1370</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2855</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A CLEAN ME
threads.message:
At least resistance to ground at L7550.
I can only think about bad CPU.
Of course, could be just a simple corroded resistor somewhere.

Just in case, check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.
Do the same for the LPC bus resistors.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1370</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2855</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A CLEAN ME
threads.message:
L7550 has 15 ohms to ground (similar to L7510).
All  SPI Bus Series Termination resistors  are OK.
LPC bus resistors  are ok

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1370</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2855</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A CLEAN ME
threads.message:
Then bad PCH, CPU, or underneath corrosion.
Heat them with quality flux.
